section.title: $LJHOME Environment Variable
section.para: Be aware that nearly all LiveJournal code depends on the $LJHOME environment variable being set to the top-level directory that LiveJournal is installed at.

note.title: Other shells
note.para: If you use another shell interface, you might be able to see what it reads on start-up by looking for the file: ~/.profile. Please refer to the documentation provided with your shell, which can usually be found by typing: $ help

note.title: Windows Environment Variables
note.para:
Defining a environment variable varies on the different Windows OS systems
For more information, please refer to : Windows 95/98/ME
Add an environment variable titled LJHOME to the autoexec.bat file, and define the variable with your install directory, such as LJHOME=C:\lj
Restart Windows for the change to take effect.
Windows NT/2000/XP
On the Start menu, point to Settings, then click Control Panel.
In the Control Panel, double click System.
In the System Properties dialog box, click the Environment tab, and specify an environment variable named LJHOME, with the value of your install directory (C:\lj or something similar).
Exit the development environment and restart it for the changed environment variable to take effect.

formalpara.title: Installing from CVS
formalpara.para: If you have CVS installed, you can anonymously checkout the LiveJournal repository by issuing the following commands: $ cd /home/lj $ touch CVSPASS $ cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@danga.com:/home/cvslj co livejournal

Installing straight from CVS gives you the latest version possible that LiveJournal offers.
CVS installs might not be as stable as tarball releases.
